A Unified Analysis of Federated Learning with Arbitrary Client Participation

Shiqiang Wang
IBM T. J. Watson Research Center
Yorktown Heights, NY 10598
wangshiq@us.ibm.com
&Mingyue Ji
Department of ECE, University of Utah
Salt Lake City, UT 84112
mingyue.ji@utah.edu
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) faces challenges of intermittent client availability and computation/communication efficiency. As a result, only a small subset of clients can participate in FL at a given time. It is important to understand how partial client participation affects convergence, but most existing works have either considered idealized participation patterns or obtained results with non-zero optimality error for generic patterns. In this paper, we provide a unified convergence analysis for FL with arbitrary client participation. We first introduce a generalized version of federated averaging (FedAvg) that amplifies parameter updates at an interval of multiple FL rounds. Then, we present a novel analysis that captures the effect of client participation in a single term. By analyzing this term, we obtain convergence upper bounds for a wide range of participation patterns, including both non-stochastic and stochastic cases, which match either the lower bound of stochastic gradient descent (SGD) or the state-of-the-art results in specific settings. We also discuss various insights, recommendations, and experimental results.

1 Introduction

We consider a federated learning (FL) problem with N𝑁N clients [17, 20, 38]. Our goal is to minimize:

f​(𝐱):=1N​∑n=1NFn​(𝐱),assign𝑓𝐱1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱\displaystyle\textstyle f(\mathbf{x}):=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}F_{n}(\mathbf{x}), (1)

where 𝐱∈ℝm𝐱superscriptℝ𝑚\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{m} is an m𝑚m-dimensional model parameter. The local objective Fn​(𝐱)subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱F_{n}(\mathbf{x}) of each client n𝑛n is usually defined as Fn​(𝐱):=𝔼ξn∼𝒟n​[ℓn​(𝐱,ξn)]assignsubscript𝐹𝑛𝐱subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝜉𝑛subscript𝒟𝑛delimited-[]subscriptℓ𝑛𝐱subscript𝜉𝑛F_{n}(\mathbf{x}):=\mathbb{E}_{\xi_{n}\sim\mathcal{D}_{n}}\left[\ell_{n}(\mathbf{x},\xi_{n})\right], where 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} is the distribution of client n𝑛n’s local data, which cannot be observed globally because the data remains private, and ℓn​(𝐱,ξ)subscriptℓ𝑛𝐱𝜉\ell_{n}(\mathbf{x},\xi) is the per-sample loss function for parameter 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} and input data ξ𝜉\xi. The objective (1) can be extended to a weighted average, but we do not write out the weights and consider them as part of ℓn​(𝐱,ξ)subscriptℓ𝑛𝐱𝜉\ell_{n}(\mathbf{x},\xi) and Fn​(𝐱)subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱F_{n}(\mathbf{x}). A canonical way of solving (1) is to use federated averaging (FedAvg) [24], which is a form of stochastic gradient descent (SGD) that operates in multiple rounds, where each round includes multiple local update steps followed by communication between clients and a server to synchronize the updates.

Partial Participation. A major challenge in FL is that clients only intermittently participate in the collaborative training process [3]. The reason is twofold. First, FL applications usually have a large pool of clients. It is impractical to have all clients participating in all FL rounds, because it would require computation and communication that can consume a large amount of energy and also lead to network congestion. Second, clients may become unavailable from time to time. For example, if the client devices are smartphones, they may be willing to participate in FL only when they are charging (usually at night), to avoid draining the battery in outdoor environments where no charger is available.

Open Problem. The convergence of FL algorithms with realistic client participation patterns has not been fully understood. Most existing works on partial participation have only considered idealized scenarios, such as those where clients are randomly selected according to a given probability distribution that is independent across rounds [4, 8, 9, 18, 21, 22, 36]. They cannot incorporate cases where clients are unavailable for a period of time. Some recent results considering general scenarios either include a constant error term that does not vanish at convergence [37, 5] or are otherwise less competitive than state-of-the-art results obtained in idealized settings [12, 35]. Therefore, we ask:
1. What classes of participation patterns have guaranteed convergence to zero error?
2. For these classes, can the convergence rate match with that obtained in idealized scenarios?

To answer these questions, we need to overcome two challenges. First, we need to devise a unified analytical methodology for obtaining the convergence rates under various participation patterns. Second, we need a general and realistic algorithm for cross-device FL, with appropriate control options that can be configured to make the convergence rate competitive.

Our Contributions. In this paper, we overcome these challenges and give answers to the two questions above. We first introduce a generalized version of FedAvg, which amplifies the parameter updates after every P𝑃P rounds, for some P≥1𝑃1P\geq 1. When P=1𝑃1P=1, our setting is the same as FedAvg with two-sided learning rates [18, 36], but we focus on an extended setup where P𝑃P can be greater than one. For this generalized FedAvg algorithm, we perform a new convergence analysis that unifies the effect of partial participation into a single term (δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) in Section 3). This allows us to decouple our main convergence analysis from the analysis on partial participation, which largely simplifies the analytical procedure. Our novel methodology gives the results shown in Table 1, for a broad range of participation patterns. These patterns include non-stochastic and regularized participation, where all clients participate equally but not simultaneously within P𝑃P rounds, and stochastic participation settings including ergodic, stationary and strongly mixing (e.g., Markov process), and independent. For the stochastic participation, we provide both expected and high probability convergence bounds, where the expected rates match the state-of-the-art FedAvg convergence rates that were derived for the idealized setting of random participation following an independent distribution. Furthermore, we provide new insights related to non-IID data, amplification of updates, “linear speedup” [39], etc.

To summarize, our main contributions are as follows:

  • •

    We introduce a generalized FedAvg algorithm which amplifies the updates aggregated over multiple rounds, where the amplification interval P𝑃P can be tuned for the best convergence.

  • •

    We present novel analysis and unified methodology for obtaining competitive convergence upper bounds with arbitrary client participation patterns.

  • •

    We discuss important insights from both the theoretical and experimental results.

Related Work. FedAvg [24] is characterized by partial client participation and multiple local updates in each round. In the case of full participation, FedAvg is also known as local SGD [10, 14, 23, 28, 29, 30] and parallel restarted SGD [40]. Partial participation was considered in [4, 8, 9, 18, 21, 22, 36], with the assumption that clients are selected to participate probabilistically according to a given distribution that is independent across rounds. Some recent works have started to incorporate unavailable clients. For example, the work in [27] allows inactive clients, but the theoretical result does not guarantee convergence if a client participates with zero probability in a certain round. Similarly, the result in [37, 5] includes a constant error term in the case of general participation in cross-device FL. Other works have obtained convergence rates related to the maximum number of inactive rounds, based on additional assumptions such as Hessian Lipschitz [12] and bounded gradient norm [35]. Their theory also requires all clients to participate once at the beginning (see [12, Remark 5.2]). In contrast, our result in this paper is based on a minimal set of assumptions. We consider a simple algorithm without requiring initial full participation, and we provide a better rate of convergence to zero error (see Table 1). Moreover, existing methods usually have separate analyses and results for each specific class of participation pattern, whereas we present a unified framework that largely simplifies the analytical procedure. Some more discussions on related works are in Appendix A.

2 Generalized FedAvg with Amplified Updates

We consider a generalized version of FedAvg as shown in Algorithm 1. In this algorithm, we define qtnsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛q_{t}^{n} to be the participation weight of client n𝑛n in round t𝑡t. If qtn=0superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛0q_{t}^{n}=0, the client does not participate in this round. Each client n𝑛n participates whenever qtn>0superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛0q_{t}^{n}>0, where the weight qtnsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛q_{t}^{n} is applied in the global update step in Line 1. For mathematical convenience in our analysis, we assume in Algorithm 1 that all clients compute their local updates in Lines 1–1, regardless of whether they participate in the current round or not. We emphasize that this is logically equivalent to the practical setting where non-participating clients do not compute, because their computations have no effect in subsequent rounds when qtn=0superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛0q_{t}^{n}=0 (see Line 1). In every round t𝑡t, each client n𝑛n computes I𝐼I steps of local updates according to Line 1, where γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 is the local learning rate and 𝐠n​(𝐲t,in)subscript𝐠𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑡𝑖𝑛\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{y}_{t,i}^{n}) is the stochastic gradient of Fn​(𝐲t,in)subscript𝐹𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑡𝑖𝑛F_{n}(\mathbf{y}_{t,i}^{n}) such that 𝔼​[𝐠n​(𝐲t,in)|𝐲t,in]=∇Fn​(𝐲t,in)𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝐠𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑡𝑖𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑡𝑖𝑛∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑡𝑖𝑛\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{y}_{t,i}^{n})\right|\mathbf{y}_{t,i}^{n}\right]=\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{y}_{t,i}^{n}).

Starting at round t0subscript𝑡0t_{0}, the global updates are accumulated in 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u} for P𝑃P rounds (Line 1). At the end of every interval of P𝑃P rounds, an amplification is applied to the accumulated updates (Line 1). Since 𝐱tsubscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{x}_{t} is first updated without amplification in rounds t0,…,t0+P−1subscript𝑡0…subscript𝑡0𝑃1t_{0},\ldots,t_{0}+P-1, Line 1 adds 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u} after multiplying η−1𝜂1\eta-1, which is equivalent to setting 𝐱t+1subscript𝐱𝑡1\mathbf{x}_{t+1} to 𝐱t0+η​𝐮subscript𝐱subscript𝑡0𝜂𝐮\mathbf{x}_{t_{0}}+\eta\mathbf{u}. When η=1𝜂1\eta=1, there is no amplification and Line 1 has no effect in this case. In general, we allow any η>0𝜂0\eta>0 including values of η𝜂\eta that are less than one. When η<1𝜂1\eta<1, we reduce (instead of amplify) the updates. Intuitively, amplification with η>1𝜂1\eta>1 is usually preferred over reduction, because we can compute the gradients on similar model parameters in each round where only a small number of clients participates. After P𝑃P rounds, the accumulated updates provide a better estimation for the overall client population, and amplifying the updates allows the model parameter to progress towards the descent direction for the majority of clients (see Appendix B.1 for an example). Also note that although P𝑃P is a parameter in our algorithm, the dominant terms of our convergence upper bounds shown in Table 1 do not depend on P𝑃P.

3 Convergence Analysis and Main Result

We analyze Algorithm 1 as follows. For ease of analysis, we assume that ∑n=1Nqtn=1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}=1 for qtn≥0superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛0q_{t}^{n}\geq 0 for all t𝑡t.111When ∑n=1Nqtn≠1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\neq 1, the algorithm is equivalent to the case of {qtn}superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛\{q_{t}^{n}\} normalized to one and a global learning rate applied to the updates in each round. Since we already amplify the updates every P𝑃P rounds, we do not apply a separate global learning rate to each round. We also define ρ𝜌\rho such that ∑n=1N(qtn)2≤ρ2superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛2superscript𝜌2\sum_{n=1}^{N}(q_{t}^{n})^{2}\leq\rho^{2} for all t𝑡t. As ∑n=1Nqtn=1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}=1, there always exists ρ𝜌\rho such that ρ2≤1superscript𝜌21\rho^{2}\leq 1. We define 𝒬:={qtn:∀n,t}assign𝒬conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛for-all𝑛𝑡\mathcal{Q}:=\{q_{t}^{n}:\forall n,t\}. Mathematically, we use the conditional expectation 𝔼[⋅|𝒬]\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\cdot\right|\mathcal{Q}\right] to denote the case where 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is given and the expectation is only over the stochastic gradient noise. In the case where 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is stochastic, the full expectation 𝔼​[⋅]𝔼delimited-[]⋅\mathbb{E}\left[\cdot\right] is taken over both the noise and 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}. We make the following assumptions that are commonly used in the literature.

Assumption 1 (Lipschitz gradient).
‖∇Fn​(𝐱)−∇Fn​(𝐲)‖≤L​‖𝐱−𝐲‖,∀𝐱,𝐲,n.norm∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐲𝐿norm𝐱𝐲for-all𝐱𝐲𝑛\displaystyle\left\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{y})\right\|\leq L\left\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\|,\forall\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y},n. (2)
Assumption 2 (Unbiased stochastic gradient with bounded variance).
𝔼​[𝐠n​(𝐱)|𝐱]=∇Fn​(𝐱)​ and𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝐠𝑛𝐱𝐱∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱 and\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x})\right|\mathbf{x}\right]=\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})\textnormal{ and } 𝔼​[‖𝐠n​(𝐱)−∇Fn​(𝐱)‖2|𝐱]≤σ2,∀𝐱,n.𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormsubscript𝐠𝑛𝐱∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱2𝐱superscript𝜎2for-all𝐱𝑛\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\left\|\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})\right\|^{2}\right|\mathbf{x}\right]\leq\sigma^{2},\forall\mathbf{x},n. (3)
Assumption 3 (Bounded gradient divergence).
‖∇Fn​(𝐱)−∇f​(𝐱)‖2≤d2,∀𝐱,n.superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱∇𝑓𝐱2superscript𝑑2for-all𝐱𝑛\displaystyle\left\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right\|^{2}\leq d^{2},\forall\mathbf{x},n. (4)

The gradient divergence in Assumption 3 is related to the degree of non-IID data distribution across clients. To better interpret how different divergence components affect the convergence, we introduce an alternative set of divergence bounds in Assumption \NoHyper3’\endNoHyper as follows. We will show later (in Section 4) that if Assumption 3 holds, then Assumption \NoHyper3’\endNoHyper also holds with properly chosen β~2superscript~𝛽2\tilde{\beta}^{2}, ν~2superscript~𝜈2\tilde{\nu}^{2}, and δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P).

Assumption \NoHyper3’\endNoHyper (Alternative gradient divergence bound).
‖∑n=1Nqtn​[∇Fn​(𝐱)−∇f​(𝐱)]‖2≤β~2,∀𝐱,t,superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛delimited-[]∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱∇𝑓𝐱2superscript~𝛽2for-all𝐱𝑡\displaystyle\textstyle\left\|\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\left[\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right]\right\|^{2}\leq\tilde{\beta}^{2},\forall\mathbf{x},t, (5)
∑n=1Nqtn​‖∇Fn​(𝐱)−∑n′=1Nqtn′​∇Fn′​(𝐱)‖2≤ν~2,∀𝐱,t,superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑛′1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡superscript𝑛′∇subscript𝐹superscript𝑛′𝐱2superscript~𝜈2for-all𝐱𝑡\displaystyle\textstyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\left\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n^{\prime}}\nabla F_{n^{\prime}}(\mathbf{x})\right\|^{2}\leq\tilde{\nu}^{2},\forall\mathbf{x},t, (6)
‖1P​∑t=t0t0+P−1∑n=1Nqtn​(∇Fn​(𝐱)−∇f​(𝐱))‖2≤δ~2​(P),∀𝐱,t0.superscriptnorm1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑡subscript𝑡0subscript𝑡0𝑃1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱∇𝑓𝐱2superscript~𝛿2𝑃for-all𝐱subscript𝑡0\displaystyle\textstyle\left\|\frac{1}{P}\sum_{t={t_{0}}}^{{t_{0}}+P-1}\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\left(\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right)\right\|^{2}\leq\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P),\forall\mathbf{x},t_{0}. (7)

In the above, β~2superscript~𝛽2\tilde{\beta}^{2} and ν~2superscript~𝜈2\tilde{\nu}^{2} capture the gradient divergence in an arbitrary round t𝑡t, and δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) captures the divergence of time-averaged gradients over P𝑃P rounds, which is a function of P𝑃P. In particular, β~2superscript~𝛽2\tilde{\beta}^{2} is an upper bound of the divergence between the original objective’s gradient ∇f​(𝐱)∇𝑓𝐱\nabla f(\mathbf{x}) and the averaged gradient among participating clients weighted by {qnt}superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛𝑡\{q_{n}^{t}\}. When all the clients participate, we have qtn=1Nsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛1𝑁q_{t}^{n}=\frac{1}{N} and (5) holds with β~2=0superscript~𝛽20\tilde{\beta}^{2}=0. The quantity ν~2superscript~𝜈2\tilde{\nu}^{2} is an upper bound of the divergence between each client’s gradient and the averaged gradient of participating clients, where the average is also weighted by {qnt}superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛𝑡\{q_{n}^{t}\}. We will show in Section 4.1 that the overall divergence d2superscript𝑑2d^{2} in Assumption 3 can be expressed as a sum of β~2superscript~𝛽2\tilde{\beta}^{2} and ν~2superscript~𝜈2\tilde{\nu}^{2}, as intuition suggests. The quantity δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) in (7) extends β~2superscript~𝛽2\tilde{\beta}^{2} in (5) by computing the average over P𝑃P rounds (inside the norm) instead of a single round. When the weights {qnt}superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛𝑡\{q_{n}^{t}\} are properly chosen, as P𝑃P gets large, the average qntsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑛𝑡q_{n}^{t} over P𝑃P rounds gets close to each other for different n𝑛n, and δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) becomes small. We will formally analyze this behavior in Section 4.2.

In the following, let ℱ:=f​(𝐱0)−f∗assignℱ𝑓subscript𝐱0superscript𝑓\mathcal{F}:=f(\mathbf{x}_{0})-f^{*}, where f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} is the true minimum of (1), i.e., f∗:=min𝐱⁡f​(𝐱)assignsuperscript𝑓subscript𝐱𝑓𝐱f^{*}:=\min_{\mathbf{x}}f(\mathbf{x}).

Proof Sketch.

We first use smoothness to relate f​(𝐱t0+P)𝑓subscript𝐱subscript𝑡0𝑃f(\mathbf{x}_{t_{0}+P}) and f​(𝐱t0)𝑓subscript𝐱subscript𝑡0f(\mathbf{x}_{t_{0}}), which includes an inner-product term that can be expanded into several terms. We upper bound this term with three other terms including ‖𝐲t,in−∑n′=1Nqtn′​𝐲t,in′‖2superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐲𝑛𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑛′1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡superscript𝑛′subscriptsuperscript𝐲superscript𝑛′𝑡𝑖2\left\|\mathbf{y}^{n}_{t,i}-\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n^{\prime}}\mathbf{y}^{n^{\prime}}_{t,i}\right\|^{2}, ‖∑n′=1Nqtn′​𝐲t,in′−𝐱t0‖2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑛′1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡superscript𝑛′subscriptsuperscript𝐲superscript𝑛′𝑡𝑖subscript𝐱subscript𝑡02\left\|\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n^{\prime}}\mathbf{y}^{n^{\prime}}_{t,i}-\mathbf{x}_{{t_{0}}}\right\|^{2}, and δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P). The upper bounds of the first two terms are found by solving recurrence relations, where the recurrence for the second term includes the first term. This nested recurrence is a uniqueness in this proof. The full proof is given in Appendix C. ∎

For two specific (but different) learning rate configurations, we can obtain the following corollaries.

Corollary 3.2.

Choosing γ=112​L​I​P​T𝛾112𝐿𝐼𝑃𝑇\gamma=\frac{1}{12LIP\sqrt{T}} and η=min⁡{12​P​L​I​ℱσ​ρ;12​T}𝜂12𝑃𝐿𝐼ℱ𝜎𝜌12𝑇\eta=\min\left\{\frac{12P\sqrt{LI\mathcal{F}}}{\sigma\rho};12\sqrt{T}\right\}, for P≤T2𝑃𝑇2P\leq\frac{T}{2}, we have

mint⁡𝔼​[‖∇f​(𝐱t)‖2|𝒬]≤𝒪​(σ​ρ​L​ℱI​T+L​P​ℱT+ν~2P2​T+β~2T+δ~2​(P)+σ2I​P​T).subscript𝑡𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡2𝒬𝒪𝜎𝜌𝐿ℱ𝐼𝑇𝐿𝑃ℱ𝑇superscript~𝜈2superscript𝑃2𝑇superscript~𝛽2𝑇superscript~𝛿2𝑃superscript𝜎2𝐼𝑃𝑇\displaystyle\min_{t}\,\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t}})\right\|^{2}\right|\mathcal{Q}\right]\leq\mathcal{O}\Bigg{(}\frac{\sigma\rho\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}}{\sqrt{IT}}\!+\!\frac{LP\mathcal{F}}{T}\!+\!\frac{\tilde{\nu}^{2}}{P^{2}T}\!+\!\frac{\tilde{\beta}^{2}}{T}\!+\!\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)\!+\!\frac{\sigma^{2}}{IPT}\Bigg{)}. (9)
Corollary 3.3.

If ℱρ​L​I​T≤1L​I​Pℱ𝜌𝐿𝐼𝑇1𝐿𝐼𝑃\frac{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}}{\rho\sqrt{LIT}}\leq\frac{1}{LIP}, choosing γ=112​L​I​P​T𝛾112𝐿𝐼𝑃𝑇\gamma=\frac{1}{12LIP\sqrt{T}} and η=12​P​L​I​ℱρ𝜂12𝑃𝐿𝐼ℱ𝜌\eta=\frac{12P\sqrt{LI\mathcal{F}}}{\rho}, for P≤T2𝑃𝑇2P\leq\frac{T}{2}, we have

mint⁡𝔼​[‖∇f​(𝐱t)‖2|𝒬]≤𝒪​((1+σ2)​ρ​L​ℱI​T+ν~2P2​T+β~2T+δ~2​(P)+σ2I​P​T).subscript𝑡𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡2𝒬𝒪1superscript𝜎2𝜌𝐿ℱ𝐼𝑇superscript~𝜈2superscript𝑃2𝑇superscript~𝛽2𝑇superscript~𝛿2𝑃superscript𝜎2𝐼𝑃𝑇\displaystyle\min_{t}\,\mathbb{E}\left[\left.\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t}})\right\|^{2}\right|\mathcal{Q}\right]\leq\mathcal{O}\Bigg{(}\!\frac{(1\!+\!\sigma^{2})\rho\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}}{\sqrt{IT}}\!+\!\frac{\tilde{\nu}^{2}}{P^{2}T}\!+\!\frac{\tilde{\beta}^{2}}{T}\!+\!\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)\!+\!\frac{\sigma^{2}}{IPT}\!\Bigg{)}.\! (10)

These two corollaries are key building blocks of our unified convergence analysis framework. The choice between them depends on whether and how fast P𝑃P grows with T𝑇T. We will also see in the next section that δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) is key in capturing the effect of different participation patterns. After deriving δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) such that (7) holds, plugging it back to one of the above corollaries gives the results in Table 1.

4 Interpreting and Applying the Unified Framework

4.1 Discussion on β~2superscript~𝛽2\tilde{\beta}^{2} and ν~2superscript~𝜈2\tilde{\nu}^{2}: Decomposition of Divergence

In Corollaries 3.2 and 3.3, we have an interesting observation that the term involving ν~~𝜈\tilde{\nu} decreases with P𝑃P, whereas the term involving β~~𝛽\tilde{\beta} does not decrease with P𝑃P. This suggests that when P𝑃P is large, the divergence term β~~𝛽\tilde{\beta} has the main effect on convergence. We recall that ν~~𝜈\tilde{\nu} captures the divergence between the gradient of each client and the average gradient of clients that participate in a round t𝑡t. Since the learning rate γ𝛾\gamma is inversely proportional to both I𝐼I and P𝑃P, a large P𝑃P gives a smaller learning rate which makes the divergence (related to ν~~𝜈\tilde{\nu}) after I𝐼I iterations in each round less significant. For the term with β~~𝛽\tilde{\beta}, increasing P𝑃P does not have the same effect, because parameter averaging is only conducted across the participating clients instead of all the clients, and β~~𝛽\tilde{\beta} captures the divergence with respect to all the clients. The effect of all clients’ participation pattern is captured by the term δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P).

From Assumption 3, by adding and subtracting ∑n′=1Nqtn′​∇Fn′​(𝐱)superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑛′1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡superscript𝑛′∇subscript𝐹superscript𝑛′𝐱\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n^{\prime}}\nabla F_{n^{\prime}}(\mathbf{x}) inside the norm and expanding the square, we can obtain

∑n=1Nqtn​‖∇Fn​(𝐱)−∇f​(𝐱)‖2superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱∇𝑓𝐱2\displaystyle\textstyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\left\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right\|^{2}
=∑n=1Nqtn​‖∇Fn​(𝐱)−∑n′=1Nqtn′​∇Fn′​(𝐱)‖2+‖∑n′=1Nqtn′​∇Fn′​(𝐱)−∇f​(𝐱)‖2≤d2,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑛′1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡superscript𝑛′∇subscript𝐹superscript𝑛′𝐱2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑛′1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡superscript𝑛′∇subscript𝐹superscript𝑛′𝐱∇𝑓𝐱2superscript𝑑2\displaystyle\textstyle=\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\left\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n^{\prime}}\nabla F_{n^{\prime}}(\mathbf{x})\right\|^{2}+\left\|\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n^{\prime}}\nabla F_{n^{\prime}}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla f(\mathbf{x})\right\|^{2}\leq d^{2}, (11)

because ∑n=1Nqtn=1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}=1 and the inner-product term is zero. The two terms in the right-hand side (RHS) of (11) are equal to the left-hand side (LHS) of (5) and (6), respectively. We thus have the following result showing that β~2superscript~𝛽2\tilde{\beta}^{2} and ν~2superscript~𝜈2\tilde{\nu}^{2} can be seen as a decomposition of the original divergence d2superscript𝑑2d^{2}.

Proposition 4.1.

There exist β~2superscript~𝛽2\tilde{\beta}^{2} and ν~2superscript~𝜈2\tilde{\nu}^{2}, such that β~2+ν~2≤d2superscript~𝛽2superscript~𝜈2superscript𝑑2\tilde{\beta}^{2}+\tilde{\nu}^{2}\leq d^{2} while satisfying (5) and (6).

The results in Theorem 3.1 and Corollaries 3.2 and 3.3 include a term of δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P). To guarantee convergence to zero error, δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) needs to be either equal to zero or decrease in T𝑇T.

Interpreting δ~2​(P)superscript~δ2P\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) Using Variance. The condition for δ~2​(P)=0superscript~𝛿2𝑃0\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=0 may be too stringent for some practical scenarios of FL. (​13​)≤N​∑n=1N[qt0n¯−μt0]2​d2,italic-(13italic-)𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptdelimited-[]¯superscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑛subscript𝜇subscript𝑡02superscript𝑑2\displaystyle\textstyle\eqref{eq:deltaExpression}\leq N\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left[\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}-\mu_{t_{0}}\right]^{2}d^{2}, (15)

Therefore, we can obtain δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) by analyzing the statistical properties of qt0n¯−μt0¯superscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑛subscript𝜇subscript𝑡0\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}-\mu_{t_{0}} and then choosing δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) to be equal to the RHS of (15).

We immediately have the following result.

Proposition 4.4 (Ergodic participation).

If {qtn:∀t}conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛for-all𝑡\{q_{t}^{n}:\forall t\} is a mean-ergodic process for any n∈{1,…,N}𝑛1…𝑁n\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, which means that limP→∞𝔼​[(qt0n¯−μt0)2]=0subscript→𝑃𝔼delimited-[]superscript¯superscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑛subscript𝜇subscript𝑡020\textstyle\lim_{P\rightarrow\infty}\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}-\mu_{t_{0}}\right)^{2}\right]=0 for any n𝑛n and t0subscript𝑡0t_{0}, then there exists δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) such that limP→∞δ~2​(P)=0subscript→𝑃superscript~𝛿2𝑃0\lim_{P\rightarrow\infty}\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=0 while satisfying (7) in expectation.

Next, we consider the class of stationary and strongly mixing processes. Informally, a random process is said to be strongly mixing with coefficient α​(P)𝛼𝑃\alpha(P) if the outcomes that are at least P𝑃P steps apart are nearly independent, where the distance between the joint probability distribution of the outcomes and their independent counterpart is at most α​(P)𝛼𝑃\alpha(P). See [2, Sec. 27] for a formal definition. A specific example of stationary and strongly mixing processes is finite-state irreducible and aperiodic Markov chains, which have an α​(P)𝛼𝑃\alpha(P) that exponentially decreases in P𝑃P [2, Thm. 8.9]. It is known that the following (generalized) central limit theorem holds for stationary and strongly mixing processes, where we adapt the result to our participation weights.

Lemma 4.5 ([2, Thm. 27.4]).

If {qtn:∀t}conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛for-all𝑡\{q_{t}^{n}:\forall t\} is stationary and strongly mixing with α​(P)=𝒪​(P−5)𝛼𝑃𝒪superscript𝑃5\alpha(P)=\mathcal{O}(P^{-5}), for any n∈{1,…,N}𝑛1…𝑁n\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, then qt0n¯∼𝒩​(μt0,υ^2P)similar-to¯superscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑛𝒩subscript𝜇subscript𝑡0superscript^𝜐2𝑃\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}\sim\mathcal{N}\left(\mu_{t_{0}},\frac{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{P}\right) for any t0subscript𝑡0t_{0} when P→∞→𝑃P\rightarrow\infty, where 𝒩​(⋅,⋅)𝒩⋅⋅\mathcal{N}(\cdot,\cdot) denotes the normal distribution and υ^2:=Var​(qt0n)+2​∑p=1∞Cov​(qt0n,qt0+pn)assignsuperscript^𝜐2Varsuperscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑝1Covsuperscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑝𝑛\hat{\upsilon}^{2}:=\mathrm{Var}(q_{t_{0}}^{n})+2\sum_{p=1}^{\infty}\mathrm{Cov}(q_{t_{0}}^{n},q_{t_{0}+p}^{n}).

From the definition of strongly mixing, we know that Cov​(qt0n,qt0+pn)Covsuperscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑝𝑛\mathrm{Cov}(q_{t_{0}}^{n},q_{t_{0}+p}^{n}) in the definition of υ^2superscript^𝜐2\hat{\upsilon}^{2} approaches zero as p𝑝p gets large, hence ∑p=1∞Cov​(qt0n,qt0+pn)superscriptsubscript𝑝1Covsuperscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑝𝑛\sum_{p=1}^{\infty}\mathrm{Cov}(q_{t_{0}}^{n},q_{t_{0}+p}^{n}) converges to a finite value. When P→∞→𝑃P\rightarrow\infty and α​(P)=𝒪​(P−5)𝛼𝑃𝒪superscript𝑃5\alpha(P)=\mathcal{O}(P^{-5}), Lemma 4.5 shows that Var​(qt0n¯)=υ^2PVar¯superscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑛superscript^𝜐2𝑃\mathrm{Var}\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}\right)=\frac{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{P}. Chebyshev’s inequality gives

Pr⁡{(qt0n¯−μt0)2≤υ^2c​P}≥1−c.Prsuperscript¯superscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑛subscript𝜇subscript𝑡02superscript^𝜐2𝑐𝑃1𝑐\displaystyle\textstyle\Pr\left\{\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}-\mu_{t_{0}}\right)^{2}\leq\frac{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{cP}\right\}\geq 1-c. (16)

Plugging Var​(qt0n¯)=𝔼​[(qt0n¯−μt0)2]=υ^2PVar¯superscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑛subscript𝔼absentdelimited-[]superscript¯superscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑛subscript𝜇subscript𝑡02superscript^𝜐2𝑃\mathrm{Var}\!\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}\right)\!=\!\mathbb{E}_{\!\!}\left[\!\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}\!-\!\mu_{t_{0}}\right)^{\!2}\right]\!=\!\frac{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{P} and (qt0n¯−μt0)2≤υ^2c​Psuperscript¯superscriptsubscript𝑞subscript𝑡0𝑛subscript𝜇subscript𝑡02superscript^𝜐2𝑐𝑃\left(\overline{q_{t_{0}}^{n}}\!-\!\mu_{t_{0}}\right)^{2}\!\leq\!\frac{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{cP} into the RHS of (15) gives the following expected and high-probability results, respectively, where “w.p.” stands for “with probability”.

Proposition 4.6 (Stationary and strongly mixing participation).

If {qtn:∀t}conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛for-all𝑡\{q_{t}^{n}:\forall t\} is stationary and strongly mixing with α​(P)=𝒪​(P−5)𝛼𝑃𝒪superscript𝑃5\alpha(P)=\mathcal{O}(P^{-5}), for any n∈{1,…,N}𝑛1…𝑁n\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, then as P→∞→𝑃P\rightarrow\infty:
Choosing δ~2​(P)=N2​d2​υ^2Psuperscript~𝛿2𝑃superscript𝑁2superscript𝑑2superscript^𝜐2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=\frac{N^{2}d^{2}\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{P} satisfies (7) in expectation; δ~2​(P)=N2​d2​υ^2c​Psuperscript~𝛿2𝑃superscript𝑁2superscript𝑑2superscript^𝜐2𝑐𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=\frac{N^{2}d^{2}\hat{\upsilon}^{2}}{cP} satisfies (7) w.p. 1−c1𝑐1-c.

For independent participation, we can obtain a similar result while not requiring P→∞→𝑃P\rightarrow\infty. We have the following result by plugging into the RHS of (15).

Proposition 4.7 (Independent participation).

If {qtn:∀t}conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛for-all𝑡\{q_{t}^{n}:\forall t\} is independent across t𝑡t, for any n𝑛n, then:
Choosing δ~2​(P)=N2​d2​υ2Psuperscript~𝛿2𝑃superscript𝑁2superscript𝑑2superscript𝜐2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=\frac{N^{2}d^{2}\upsilon^{2}}{P} satisfies (7) in expectation; δ~2​(P)=N2​d2​ln⁡(2/c)2​Psuperscript~𝛿2𝑃superscript𝑁2superscript𝑑22𝑐2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P)=\frac{N^{2}d^{2}\ln\left(\nicefrac{{2}}{{c}}\right)}{2P} satisfies (7) w.p. 1−c1𝑐1\!-\!c.

Compared to Proposition 4.6, the high-probability bound in Proposition 4.7 has c𝑐c in the logarithmic term, which is tighter since 12​ln⁡(2c)≤1c−12122𝑐1𝑐12\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{2}{c}\right)\leq\frac{1}{c}-\frac{1}{2} (ignoring υ^2superscript^𝜐2\hat{\upsilon}^{2}).

Choosing PPP as a Function of TTT. The choices of δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) in Propositions 4.6 and 4.7 include P𝑃P in the denominator. Hence, we can guarantee convergence to zero error if we choose P𝑃P to be an increasing function of T𝑇T, which also ensures that P→∞→𝑃P\rightarrow\infty as T→∞→𝑇T\rightarrow\infty. If we choose P∝N52​I​Tproportional-to𝑃superscript𝑁52𝐼𝑇P\propto N^{\frac{5}{2}}\sqrt{IT}, we can obtain the following convergence rate from Corollary 3.3 together with Proposition 4.1.

Corollary 4.8 (Stochastic participation).

If the conditions of either Proposition 4.6 or Proposition 4.7 hold, and we choose P=υ^2​N52​I​T𝑃superscript^𝜐2superscript𝑁52𝐼𝑇P=\hat{\upsilon}^{2}N^{\frac{5}{2}}\sqrt{IT} or P=υ2​N52​I​T𝑃superscript𝜐2superscript𝑁52𝐼𝑇P=\upsilon^{2}N^{\frac{5}{2}}\sqrt{IT}, respectively, and the learning rates according to Corollary 3.3, then the convergence error in expectation over 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} satisfies

mint⁡𝔼​[‖∇f​(𝐱t)‖2]subscript𝑡𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡2\displaystyle\min_{t}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t}})\right\|^{2}\right] ≤𝒪​((1+σ2)​ρ​L​ℱI​T+d2N​I​T+d2+σ2T),absent𝒪1superscript𝜎2𝜌𝐿ℱ𝐼𝑇superscript𝑑2𝑁𝐼𝑇superscript𝑑2superscript𝜎2𝑇\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{O}\Bigg{(}\frac{(1+\sigma^{2})\rho\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}}{\sqrt{IT}}+\frac{d^{2}}{\sqrt{NIT}}+\frac{d^{2}+\sigma^{2}}{T}\Bigg{)}, (18)

for I≤ρυ^2​N5/2​L​ℱ𝐼𝜌superscript^𝜐2superscript𝑁52𝐿ℱI\leq\frac{\rho}{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}N^{\nicefrac{{5}}{{2}}}\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}} and T→∞→𝑇T\rightarrow\infty when using conditions of Proposition 4.6, or I≤ρυ2​N5/2​L​ℱ𝐼𝜌superscript𝜐2superscript𝑁52𝐿ℱI\leq\frac{\rho}{\upsilon^{2}N^{\nicefrac{{5}}{{2}}}\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}} and T≥4​υ4​I​N5𝑇4superscript𝜐4𝐼superscript𝑁5T\geq 4\upsilon^{4}IN^{5} when using condition of Proposition 4.7.

Remark. Although the upper bound of I𝐼I in Corollary 4.8 may appear restrictive, note that the optimal solution 𝐱∗superscript𝐱\mathbf{x}^{*} to (1) remains the same when the objective f​(𝐱)𝑓𝐱f(\mathbf{x}) is scaled by a multiplicative positive constant, which in turn scales L​ℱ𝐿ℱ\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}. More specifically, consider an arbitrary a>0𝑎0a>0, we define F′​(𝐱):=a​F​(𝐱)assignsuperscript𝐹′𝐱𝑎𝐹𝐱F^{\prime}(\mathbf{x}):=aF(\mathbf{x}) and f′​(𝐱):=1N​∑n=1NFn′​(𝐱)=a​f​(𝐱)assignsuperscript𝑓′𝐱1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐹′𝑛𝐱𝑎𝑓𝐱f^{\prime}(\mathbf{x}):=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}F^{\prime}_{n}(\mathbf{x})=af(\mathbf{x}). Then, we have f′​(𝐱0)−f′⁣∗=a​f​(𝐱0)−a​f∗=a​ℱsuperscript𝑓′subscript𝐱0superscript𝑓′𝑎𝑓subscript𝐱0𝑎superscript𝑓𝑎ℱf^{\prime}(\mathbf{x}_{0})-f^{\prime*}=af(\mathbf{x}_{0})-af^{*}=a\mathcal{F}. We also have ‖∇Fn′​(𝐱)−∇Fn′​(𝐲)‖=a​‖∇Fn​(𝐱)−∇Fn​(𝐲)‖≤a​L​‖𝐱−𝐲‖norm∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹′𝑛𝐱∇subscriptsuperscript𝐹′𝑛𝐲𝑎norm∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐲𝑎𝐿norm𝐱𝐲\left\|\nabla F^{\prime}_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F^{\prime}_{n}(\mathbf{y})\right\|=a\left\|\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{y})\right\|\leq aL\left\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\| from Assumption 1, due to the linearity of gradients. Hence, by choosing a∈(0,1)𝑎01a\in(0,1) and replacing F​(𝐱)𝐹𝐱F(\mathbf{x}) with F′​(𝐱)superscript𝐹′𝐱F^{\prime}(\mathbf{x}), we can make L​ℱ𝐿ℱ\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}} arbitrarily small and ρυ^2​N5/2​L​ℱ𝜌superscript^𝜐2superscript𝑁52𝐿ℱ\frac{\rho}{\hat{\upsilon}^{2}N^{\nicefrac{{5}}{{2}}}\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}} or ρυ2​N5/2​L​ℱ𝜌superscript𝜐2superscript𝑁52𝐿ℱ\frac{\rho}{\upsilon^{2}N^{\nicefrac{{5}}{{2}}}\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}}} (the upper bound of I𝐼I in Corollary 4.8) arbitrarily large without affecting the optimal solution 𝐱∗superscript𝐱\mathbf{x}^{*}. Thus, we can potentially allow arbitrarily large I𝐼I by scaling f​(𝐱)𝑓𝐱f(\mathbf{x}) without changing the optimal solution 𝐱∗superscript𝐱\mathbf{x}^{*}. We leave the in-depth study of this phenomenon for future work, where we recognize that such a scaling will affect the LHS of the convergence bound too, although the optimal solution 𝐱∗superscript𝐱\mathbf{x}^{*} does not change.

We also give the following further insight related to Corollary 4.8. In Corollary 4.8, we choose P𝑃P to be proportional to the variance υ^2superscript^𝜐2\hat{\upsilon}^{2} or υ2superscript𝜐2\upsilon^{2}. This is intuitive because when the clients’ participation weights have higher variance, we would like to wait for more rounds before amplifying, so that the contributions of clients are more balanced. In the same way, P𝑃P increases with the number of clients N𝑁N. Recall that ∑n=1Nqtn=1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}=1. Intuitively, when the participation patterns of individual clients remain “unchanged”, qtnsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛q_{t}^{n} scales with 1N1𝑁\frac{1}{N} and its variance υ^2superscript^𝜐2\hat{\upsilon}^{2} or υ2superscript𝜐2\upsilon^{2} scales with 1N21superscript𝑁2\frac{1}{N^{2}}, so the product υ^2​N52∼Nsimilar-tosuperscript^𝜐2superscript𝑁52𝑁\hat{\upsilon}^{2}N^{\frac{5}{2}}\sim\sqrt{N} or υ2​N52∼Nsimilar-tosuperscript𝜐2superscript𝑁52𝑁\upsilon^{2}N^{\frac{5}{2}}\sim\sqrt{N}, implying that P𝑃P effectively scales with N𝑁\sqrt{N} when this intuition holds.

While the result in Corollary 4.8 is in expectation, the high-probability bound is similar (see Table 1). In general, since (7) is used as an upper bound in the proof of Theorem 3.1, if δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) is chosen so that (7) holds in expectation or with a certain probability, such as in Propositions 4.4, 4.6 and 4.7, then the final convergence result also holds in expectation or with a certain probability, respectively.

5 Discussions and Insights

Interpretation of “Linear Speedup”. Linear speedup is a desirable property seen in existing works that consider idealized client participation [39, 40, 36]. It essence, it means that the same convergence error can be achieved by increasing the number of participating clients S𝑆S (with S≤N𝑆𝑁S\leq N) and reducing the number of rounds T𝑇T, while keeping the product S​T𝑆𝑇ST unchanged. In our case of arbitrary client participation, the coefficient ρ𝜌\rho is a generalization of the 1/S1𝑆\nicefrac{{1}}{{\sqrt{S}}} term for linear speedup in existing works that select a fixed number of S𝑆S clients in each round. When S𝑆S clients participate with equal weight, because ∑n=1Nqtn=1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}=1, we have qtn=1/Ssuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛1𝑆q_{t}^{n}=\nicefrac{{1}}{{S}} for the participating clients and qtn=0superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛0q_{t}^{n}=0 for the non-participating clients, so ρ=[∑n=1N(qtn)2]1/2=1/S𝜌superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛2121𝑆\rho=\big{[}\sum_{n=1}^{N}(q_{t}^{n})^{2}\big{]}^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}=\nicefrac{{1}}{{\sqrt{S}}}. Plugging this ρ𝜌\rho back to the convergence results, we achieve a convergence rate of 𝒪​(σ/S​I​T)𝒪𝜎𝑆𝐼𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{\sigma}}{{\sqrt{SIT}}}\right) in Corollary 4.3 and 𝒪​((1+σ2)/S​I​T)𝒪1superscript𝜎2𝑆𝐼𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{(1+\sigma^{2})}}{{\sqrt{SIT}}}\right) in Corollary 4.8, for sufficiently large T𝑇T while ignoring the other variables in 𝒪​(⋅)𝒪⋅\mathcal{O}(\cdot), as shown in Table 1. This shows that we can achieve linear speedup in S𝑆S in this special case. We can also generalize to having at least Sminsubscript𝑆minS_{\mathrm{min}} clients participating with equal weight in each round. Following the same argument, we have ρ≤1/Smin𝜌1subscript𝑆min\rho\leq\nicefrac{{1}}{{\sqrt{S_{\mathrm{min}}}}} in this case, giving a linear speedup in Sminsubscript𝑆minS_{\mathrm{min}}. In general, we achieve a linear speedup factor of 1/ρ21superscript𝜌2\nicefrac{{1}}{{\rho^{2}}} in the case of arbitrary participation.

Matching Lower Bound or State-of-the-Art Results. We continue to assume sufficiently large T𝑇T. For regularized participation (Corollary 4.3), our convergence rate of 𝒪​(σ/S​I​T)𝒪𝜎𝑆𝐼𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{\sigma}}{{\sqrt{SIT}}}\right) matches the lower bound of convergence error for centralized SGD [1]. The lower bound states that to reach a convergence error of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, there exists an objective function such that at least Ω​(σ2/ϵ2)Ωsuperscript𝜎2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\Omega\left(\nicefrac{{\sigma^{2}}}{{\epsilon^{2}}}\right) stochastic gradient oracle calls are required.222Note that [1] defines the convergence error as ‖∇f​(𝐱t)‖norm∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t}})\right\| whereas we define it as ‖∇f​(𝐱t)‖2superscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript𝐱𝑡2\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{{t}})\right\|^{2}. Hence, the order of our ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is different from that in [1]. We have S​I​T𝑆𝐼𝑇SIT oracle calls to reach ϵ=𝒪​(σ/S​I​T)italic-ϵ𝒪𝜎𝑆𝐼𝑇\epsilon=\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{\sigma}}{{\sqrt{SIT}}}\right) according to our result, thus our upper bound matches this lower bound and is asymptotically optimal. Note that our upper bound still matches the lower bound if we include the coefficient L​ℱ𝐿ℱ\sqrt{L\mathcal{F}} in 𝒪​(⋅)𝒪⋅\mathcal{O}\left(\cdot\right) and L​ℱ𝐿ℱL\mathcal{F} in Ω​(⋅)Ω⋅\Omega\left(\cdot\right). For stochastic participation (Corollary 4.8), our convergence rate of 𝒪​((1+σ2)/S​I​T)𝒪1superscript𝜎2𝑆𝐼𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{(1+\sigma^{2})}}{{\sqrt{SIT}}}\right) matches state-of-the-art results of FedAvg [8, 18, 36] that were obtained for the more idealized case of clients being selected to participate according to a specific independent sampling scheme.

Special Case of Waiting for All Clients. We consider a specific configuration of FedAvg where all the clients wait for P𝑃P rounds before proceeding with SGD. In every iteration i𝑖i of round t𝑡t within these P𝑃P rounds, each participating client n𝑛n may call the stochastic gradient oracle to obtain 𝐠n​(𝐱t)subscript𝐠𝑛subscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x}_{t}), but it does not perform local updates. Instead, it accumulates and averages the sampled instances of 𝐠n​(𝐱t)subscript𝐠𝑛subscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x}_{t}). SGD is performed once after these P𝑃P rounds using the average 𝐠n​(𝐱t)subscript𝐠𝑛subscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x}_{t}) from each client n𝑛n. Assume that P𝑃P is large enough so that each client n𝑛n computes 𝐠n​(𝐱t)subscript𝐠𝑛subscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x}_{t}) at least M≥1𝑀1M\geq 1 times that are averaged afterwards. If the M𝑀M instances of 𝐠n​(𝐱t)subscript𝐠𝑛subscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{g}_{n}(\mathbf{x}_{t}) are all independent from each other, the noise σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} (defined in Assumption 2) becomes σ2/Msuperscript𝜎2𝑀\nicefrac{{\sigma^{2}}}{{M}}. This configuration can be considered as a special case of Algorithm 1, where all N𝑁N clients perform SGD once in P𝑃P rounds, so there are T/P𝑇𝑃\nicefrac{{T}}{{P}} updates in total, with a reduced stochastic gradient noise of σ2/Msuperscript𝜎2𝑀\nicefrac{{\sigma^{2}}}{{M}}. By replacing σ𝜎\sigma and S​I​T𝑆𝐼𝑇SIT in our bound 𝒪​(σ/S​I​T)𝒪𝜎𝑆𝐼𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{\sigma}}{{\sqrt{SIT}}}\right) with σ/M𝜎𝑀\nicefrac{{\sigma}}{{\sqrt{M}}} and N​T/P𝑁𝑇𝑃\nicefrac{{NT}}{{P}}, respectively, we obtain a convergence rate of 𝒪​(σ​P/M​N​T)𝒪𝜎𝑃𝑀𝑁𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(\nicefrac{{\sigma\sqrt{P}}}{{\sqrt{MNT}}}\right) for regularized participation with this “wait-for-all” method.

In theory, when considering regularized participation and M𝑀M is large enough, the convergence rate of this “wait-for-all” method can potentially match with that of the original configuration of Algorithm 1. In this way, the convergence error upper bound of both methods can match the lower bound of SGD convergence error (see discussion above). However, in practice, reducing the stochastic gradient noise as in this “wait-for-all” method may only give limited improvement. One reason is that practical settings have a finite number of training data samples, so the noise can only be reduced by a certain degree. In addition, having some noise in SGD can prevent the model parameter from being trapped in saddle points and local minima in practice. The empirical results in Section 6 show that Algorithm 1 with amplification performs better than waiting for all the clients. We also note that our results for stochastic participation (Corollary 4.8) does not require all the clients to participate within P𝑃P rounds.

Achieving Regularized Participation in Practice. In theory, regularized participation requires that 1P​∑t=t0t0+P−1qtn1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑡subscript𝑡0subscript𝑡0𝑃1superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛\frac{1}{P}\sum_{t={t_{0}}}^{{t_{0}}+P-1}q_{t}^{n} is equal to each other for all the clients n∈{1,…,N}𝑛1…𝑁n\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, for a properly chosen P𝑃P. When all the clients are connected to the system and client sampling is performed to limit the computation and communication overhead, this condition holds when the clients are selected according to a permutation, i.e., all the clients participate once before the same client can be selected again. In the case where clients get disconnected from time to time, the system can try to properly schedule the participation of connected clients and their weights {qtn}superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛\{q_{t}^{n}\}, so that within a cycle of P𝑃P rounds, all the clients participate with equal averaged weights. In practice, it can be sufficient if this regularized condition is only approximately satisfied, especially when multiple clients have similar datasets so that δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) is small although not necessarily zero. The empirical results in Section 6 show that Algorithm 1 with amplification can give good performance even if P𝑃P is less than the participation cycle of all clients. This suggests that, as long as the subset of clients that participate in P𝑃P rounds are more representative of the overall data distribution than the (usually much smaller) subset of clients that participate in a single round, amplifying the updates every P𝑃P rounds can be useful.

6 Experiments

We ran experiments of training convolutional neural networks (CNNs) with FashionMNIST [34] and CIFAR-10 [19] datasets, each of which has images in 101010 different classes. We set the total number of clients to N=250𝑁250N=250. Similar to existing works [36, 6, 7], we partition the data into clients so that each client has data of one majority class label, with 5%percent55\% of data of other (minority) labels, to simulate a setup with non-IID data distribution which is often encountered in FL scenarios. We assume that the clients’ availability exhibits a periodic pattern inspired by [6, 7]. Namely, in the first 100100100 rounds, only clients with the first two majority labels are available; in the next 100100100 rounds, only clients with the next two majority labels are available, and so on. In each round, S=10𝑆10S=10 clients participate in a regularized manner, out of all the currently available clients. To speed up initial rounds of training, similar to practical deep learning implementations, we start with standard FedAvg with a relatively large initial learning rate. The initial rates are γ=0.1𝛾0.1\gamma=0.1 and γ=0.05𝛾0.05\gamma=0.05 without amplification (i.e., η=1𝜂1\eta=1) for FashionMNIST and CIFAR-10, respectively, which were obtained using grid search in a separate scenario of always participation. After an initial training of 2,00020002,000 rounds for FashionMNIST and 4,00040004,000 rounds for CIFAR-10, we study the performance of different approaches with their own learning rates. Additional setup details and results are given in Appendix D.

Comparing Different Methods. We show the results of Algorithm 1 both with and without amplification. When using amplification, we set η=10𝜂10\eta=10 and P=500𝑃500P=500. We also compare to an algorithm that waits for all the clients, related to our discussion in Section 5, for two settings where each client computes its gradients either on a minibatch or on the entire dataset, which we refer to as “wait-minibatch” and “wait-full”, respectively. The best learning rate γ𝛾\gamma of each approach was separately found on a grid that is {1,0.1,0.01,0.001,0.0001}10.10.010.0010.0001\{1,0.1,0.01,0.001,0.0001\} times the initial learning rate, with the periodic participation pattern described above. The results are shown in Figure 1.

We make a few key observations as follows. First, we clearly see that Algorithm 1 with amplification gives the best performance. By choosing P=500𝑃500P=500, we match with the participation period of clients, as described in the setup above. This corresponds to our setting with regularized participation. In this case, Algorithm 1 with amplification allows different groups of clients to make small progress among themselves first. After P𝑃P rounds, each client has made its own share of contribution, and the updates get amplified so that the model parameter progresses faster towards the direction that is overall beneficial for all the clients. As our theory predicts, this approach gives a desirable convergence rate, which is now verified by experiments. Next, we observe that the “wait-minibatch” and “wait-full” methods perform worse than Algorithm 1 with amplification. We also observe that “wait-full”, which computes the gradient on the entire dataset, does not provide substantial gain compared to “wait-minibatch” in the experiments. These observations align with our discussion in Section 5 on the practical performance of different methods. Finally, we observe that standard FedAvg (i.e., Algorithm 1 without amplification) gives the lowest performance. This is because without amplification, the algorithm cannot put more emphasis on the collective updates by the cohort of all clients, and the parameter updates may diverge from the overall optimal direction.

Different Values of P𝑃P. Next, we fix η=10𝜂10\eta=10 in Algorithm 1 and study the effect of choosing different values of P𝑃P. We use the same learning rate γ𝛾\gamma that is obtained from grid search in the previous experiment. Note that the clients’ availability pattern remains the same as described above. The choice of different P𝑃P simulates the practical scenario where the estimation of P𝑃P may not perfectly align with the actual participation cycle. The results are shown in Figure 2.

We observe that P=1𝑃1P=1, which corresponds to the “classical” setting of FedAvg with two-sided learning rates [18, 36], does not give the best performance. Interestingly, compared to P=500𝑃500P=500, we see that P=100𝑃100P=100 and P=300𝑃300P=300 give a similar performance, and even slightly better performance in the case of CIFAR-10 data. Due to the random offset applied to the first participation cycle in each experiment (see Appendix D.1 for details), every interval of 100100100 rounds can include the “partial” contributions by two subsets of clients (with data in 444, out of 101010, majority classes). The results suggest that amplifying such partial contributions by multiple subsets of clients can still improve performance. In the case of CIFAR-10 data, the reason for P=500𝑃500P=500 being slightly worse may be that the accumulated update within P𝑃P rounds generally becomes larger as P𝑃P gets larger, in which case amplification causes a bigger change in the model parameter. Depending on the landscape of the loss function, this change may be too big so that the model performance decreases. For a similar reason, the performances of P=700𝑃700P=700 and P=900𝑃900P=900 are even worse. Nevertheless, we expect that choosing a smaller learning rate γ𝛾\gamma can improve the performance for large P𝑃P values.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we have studied FL with arbitrary client participation. For a generalized FedAvg algorithm that amplifies parameter updates every P𝑃P rounds, we have developed a unified framework for convergence analysis and obtained convergence rates for a variety of client participation patterns. Our findings suggest that regularized participation with finite P𝑃P gives the best performance and matches the lower bound of SGD convergence error when T𝑇T is sufficiently large. For stochastic participation, first, we have formally proven that convergence is guaranteed when the participation process is ergodic. Then, for two generic classes of participation processes, we have proven that with a properly chosen P𝑃P, our convergence rate matches state-of-the-art FedAvg convergence rates that were derived for the idealized case of independent and unbiased participation. The empirical results have confirmed that amplification is useful and also provided further insights. Future directions include analysis of advanced FL algorithms and more detailed empirical study.

Appendix A Additional Related Works

We complement Section 1 by discussing a few additional related works as follows.

Client unavailability was also studied from the perspective of block-cyclic SGD [6, 7], which trains multiple models each for a block (group) of clients with known identity and was analyzed for convex objectives. Different from those works, our goal is to train a single model without requiring block structure, and we focus on non-convex objectives that frequently arise in modern problems involving neural networks.

In the literature of SGD in the centralized setting, the effect of different ways of minibatch sampling has also been studied, such as IID sampling from an arbitrary distribution [11] and random reshuffling [13, 25]. However, the problem in FL is much more complex and needs to incorporate the diversity of different clients’ local objectives. Moreover, we focus on a unified framework that is more general than the special cases of IID sampling and random reshuffling.

FedAvg with two-sided learning rates has been studied in the literature [18, 36], where a global learning rate is applied to the updates at the end of each round, giving an improved convergence bound compared to using a single-sided learning rate. This is equivalent to our Algorithm 1 with P=1𝑃1P=1 and the amplification factor η𝜂\eta being the global learning rate. We extend this setup by allowing any P≥1𝑃1P\geq 1. Moreover, most existing works including [18, 36] have only shown the benefit of two-sided learning rates in a theoretical setting; their experiments still uses a global learning rate of 1.01.01.0, which is equivalent to the case of a single-sided learning rate. Although some recent works have used different global learning rates in experiments, the best setting often remains to be choosing 1.01.01.0 as the global learning rate in the case of FedAvg [26, Table 8]. In contrast, we have verified the benefit of amplification in our experiments (Section 6), for scenarios with more challenging client participation patterns than existing works. The idea of amplification is also related to look-ahead algorithms [42, 31], which consider a two-agent setting, e.g., a server and a single client. Different from these works, we consider the unique challenges in federated learning with multiple arbitrarily participating clients, where the data is non-IID across clients.

It is also worth pointing out that our discussion related to waiting for all clients in Section 5 has some analogy to the comparison between local SGD and minibatch SGD [32, 33, 41]. Even when not considering the effect of partial participation, these existing works have only identified some specific classes of convex objectives where local SGD can be shown to have a better theoretical convergence rate than minibatch SGD. An improved theoretical approach to capture the fact that local SGD often outperforms minibatch SGD in practice, for a wide range of problems and objective functions (especially non-convex objectives), remains an interesting future direction.

Appendix B Additional Discussions

B.1 Why Does Amplification Help?

We give an illustrative example to explain why the use of amplification with η>1𝜂1\eta>1 generally improves the performance, as shown in both our theory and experiments. Consider a simple setting with N=3𝑁3N=3 clients. Each client n𝑛n has a local objective defined as Fn​(𝐱)=12​‖𝐱−𝐳n‖2subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱12superscriptnorm𝐱subscript𝐳𝑛2F_{n}(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{2}\left\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{z}_{n}\right\|^{2} for some constant vector 𝐳n∈ℝmsubscript𝐳𝑛superscriptℝ𝑚\mathbf{z}_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{m}. It is evident that the true optimal solution that minimizes the global objective f​(𝐱)=16​∑n=13‖𝐱−𝐳n‖2𝑓𝐱16superscriptsubscript𝑛13superscriptnorm𝐱subscript𝐳𝑛2f(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{6}\sum_{n=1}^{3}\left\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{z}_{n}\right\|^{2} is 𝐱∗=13​∑n=13𝐳nsuperscript𝐱13superscriptsubscript𝑛13subscript𝐳𝑛\mathbf{x}^{*}=\frac{1}{3}\sum_{n=1}^{3}\mathbf{z}_{n}, but we assume that this is not known to the system and we would like to solve this problem using Algorithm 1. In this specific example, we consider a two-dimensional space (i.e., m=2𝑚2m=2) and define 𝐳1=(−1,0),𝐳2=(1,0),𝐳3=(0,3)formulae-sequencesubscript𝐳110formulae-sequencesubscript𝐳210subscript𝐳303\mathbf{z}_{1}=(-1,0),\mathbf{z}_{2}=(1,0),\mathbf{z}_{3}=(0,\sqrt{3}). We further assume that the three clients are available in a cyclic manner, so that in the first round, only client n=1𝑛1n=1 is available; in the second round, only client n=2𝑛2n=2 is available; in the third round, only client n=3𝑛3n=3 is available; then this cycle continues with client n=1𝑛1n=1 available in the fourth round, and so on. We plot the trajectory of how the model parameter 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} changes from the initial value 𝐱0subscript𝐱0\mathbf{x}_{0} to 𝐱15subscript𝐱15\mathbf{x}_{15} that is obtained after T=15𝑇15T=15 rounds. The initial parameter is set to 𝐱0=(1,2)subscript𝐱012\mathbf{x}_{0}=(1,2) in this example. The plots of the trajectories with different choices of local learning rate γ𝛾\gamma and amplification factor η𝜂\eta are shown in Figures B.1–B.2.

With the local objectives defined in this example, the local gradient can be directly computed as ∇Fn​(𝐱)=𝐱−𝐳n∇subscript𝐹𝑛𝐱𝐱subscript𝐳𝑛\nabla F_{n}(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{z}_{n}. Therefore, in the case of no amplification (i.e., η=1𝜂1\eta=1), the solution variable 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} moves towards 𝐳1subscript𝐳1\mathbf{z}_{1} in the first round when client n=1𝑛1n=1 is available; then, it moves towards 𝐳2subscript𝐳2\mathbf{z}_{2} in the second round when client n=2𝑛2n=2 is available, and so on. As we see from Figure B.1, this can lead to a pattern where 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} cycles around the optimal solution 𝐱∗superscript𝐱\mathbf{x}^{*} but approaches 𝐱∗superscript𝐱\mathbf{x}^{*} only very slowly, especially when γ𝛾\gamma is large. In the case of small γ𝛾\gamma, this cyclic pattern is not apparent, but we can still see that 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} moves towards different local optimal points (i.e., 𝐳nsubscript𝐳𝑛\mathbf{z}_{n} for different n𝑛n) in different rounds, and the overall convergence speed is slow. This leads to the following problem: regardless of whether we choose a large or small γ𝛾\gamma, at the end of the 151515-th round, there is an apparent gap between 𝐱15subscript𝐱15\mathbf{x}_{15} and 𝐱∗superscript𝐱\mathbf{x}^{*}.

The advantage of amplification is that it increases the importance of the aggregated updates made by clients that participate in different rounds. In this specific example, a single client’s update direction may be towards its own local optimum, which can be different from the direction towards the global optimum. However, the accumulated updates by all the three clients over every three rounds will be more likely towards the global optimum (or a neighborhood of it). By amplifying such accumulated updates after every three rounds (i.e., P=3𝑃3P=3), we can let the solution variable 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} move much faster towards the true (global) optimum. This intuition is confirmed by the trajectories shown in Figure B.2. Here, we note that the product of γ𝛾\gamma and η𝜂\eta in the corresponding sub-figures of Figures B.1 and B.2 are equal. By keeping a small local learning rate γ𝛾\gamma and amplifying the updates accumulated in every P=3𝑃3P=3 rounds, we can converge to the optimal value 𝐱∗superscript𝐱\mathbf{x}^{*}, as shown in Figure B.2.

Note that in practice, P𝑃P does not need to perfectly align with the “cycle” of participation, as seen in Figure 2 in Section 6 of the main paper.

B.2 Relating Different Participation Patterns to Practical FL Scenarios

In the following, we discuss some possible connections between practical FL application scenarios and the different participation patterns that are considered in our theoretical analysis.

The case of periodic shifts, which is often seen in practical cross-device FL scenarios, is mostly related to regularized participation. In this case, the clients participate equally over the entire period, but only a subset of clients from a specific population (and with a specific data distribution) may participate in each “period” that includes a certain number of consecutive rounds. In practice, this “equal participation” only needs to hold approximately, and our empirical results at the end of Section 6 show that our Algorithm 1 can still give good performance even if P𝑃P is less than the full cycle (period) of participation.

Among the stochastic participation patterns, ergodic is the most generic. Intuitively, it says that the participation weights of different clients are the same when averaged over a long enough time. This can represent a cross-device FL scenario, where the participation of each client at any time instance can be highly random, but the long-term average statistics of clients are the same. The case of strongly mixing participation includes the special case where the participation follows a Markov chain, i.e., if the client is currently unavailable, there is a certain (possibly small) probability that it will become available in the next round, and vice versa. This can also represent a cross-device FL setting, where the devices get connected and disconnected over time, and there is some randomness in the exact time it gets connected or disconnected. Finally, the case of independent participation may represent a cross-silo FL setting, where the reason for not participating in a certain round is not because the client is disconnected for an extended period of time, but rather because the client has some other higher-priority tasks to run so that it cannot participate in all rounds.

C.2 Lemmas

because 𝐲t,0n=𝐱tsubscriptsuperscript𝐲𝑛𝑡0subscript𝐱𝑡\mathbf{y}^{n}_{t,0}=\mathbf{x}_{t} for all n𝑛n as specified in Algorithm 1, and ∑n=1Nqtn=1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}=1 hence 𝐱t+1=𝐱t+∑n=1Nqtn​(𝐲t,In−𝐱t)=∑n=1Nqtn​𝐲t,Insubscript𝐱𝑡1subscript𝐱𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑡𝐼𝑛subscript𝐱𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑡𝐼𝑛\mathbf{x}_{t+1}=\mathbf{x}_{t}+\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}(\mathbf{y}_{t,I}^{n}-\mathbf{x}_{t})=\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\mathbf{y}_{t,I}^{n} according to Algorithm 1.

Therefore, the same recursion in (C.9) also holds between t+1𝑡1t+1 and t𝑡t, i.e.,

≤(1+59​(I​P−12))​𝔼⋅|𝒬​[‖∑n=1Nqtn​𝐲t,In−𝐱t0‖2]\displaystyle\leq\left(1+\frac{5}{9\left(IP-\frac{1}{2}\right)}\right)\mathbb{E}_{\cdot|\mathcal{Q}}\left[\left\|\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}\mathbf{y}^{n}_{t,I}-\mathbf{x}_{t_{0}}\right\|^{2}\right]
+γ2​I​ν~2P+8​I​P​γ2​β~2+8​I​P​γ2​𝔼⋅|𝒬​[‖∇f​(𝐱t0)‖2]+γ2​σ2​[ρ2+16​P​(1−∑n=1N(qtn)2)].\displaystyle\quad\quad+\frac{\gamma^{2}I\tilde{\nu}^{2}}{P}+8IP\gamma^{2}\tilde{\beta}^{2}+8IP\gamma^{2}\mathbb{E}_{\cdot|\mathcal{Q}}\left[\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t_{0}})\right\|^{2}\right]+\gamma^{2}\sigma^{2}\left[\rho^{2}+\frac{1}{6P}\left(1-\sum_{n=1}^{N}(q_{t}^{n})^{2}\right)\right]. (C.11)

because 𝐲t0,0n=𝐱t0subscriptsuperscript𝐲𝑛subscript𝑡00subscript𝐱subscript𝑡0\mathbf{y}^{n}_{t_{0},0}=\mathbf{x}_{t_{0}} for all n𝑛n as specified in Algorithm 1, and ∑n=1Nqtn=1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡𝑛1\sum_{n=1}^{N}q_{t}^{n}=1.

We combine (C.9), (C.11), and (C.12). Since t0≤t≤t0+P−1subscript𝑡0𝑡subscript𝑡0𝑃1t_{0}\leq t\leq t_{0}+P-1, unrolling the recursion gives

C.4 Proof of Corollaries 3.2 and 3.3

For Corollary 3.2, we note that γ​η=min⁡{ℱσ​ρ​L​I​T;1L​I​P}𝛾𝜂ℱ𝜎𝜌𝐿𝐼𝑇1𝐿𝐼𝑃\gamma\eta=\min\left\{\frac{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}}{\sigma\rho\sqrt{LIT}};\frac{1}{LIP}\right\} by the choice of γ𝛾\gamma and η𝜂\eta. Because γ≤112​L​I​P𝛾112𝐿𝐼𝑃\gamma\leq\frac{1}{12LIP} (since T≥1𝑇1T\geq 1) and γ​η≤1L​I​P𝛾𝜂1𝐿𝐼𝑃\gamma\eta\leq\frac{1}{LIP}, the conditions of Theorem 3.1 hold. Then, using γ​η≤ℱσ​ρ​L​I​T𝛾𝜂ℱ𝜎𝜌𝐿𝐼𝑇\gamma\eta\leq\frac{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}}{\sigma\rho\sqrt{LIT}}, 1γ​η=max⁡{σ​ρ​L​I​Tℱ;L​I​P}≤σ​ρ​L​I​Tℱ+L​I​P1𝛾𝜂𝜎𝜌𝐿𝐼𝑇ℱ𝐿𝐼𝑃𝜎𝜌𝐿𝐼𝑇ℱ𝐿𝐼𝑃\frac{1}{\gamma\eta}=\max\left\{\frac{\sigma\rho\sqrt{LIT}}{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}};LIP\right\}\leq\frac{\sigma\rho\sqrt{LIT}}{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}}+LIP, and ρ2≤1superscript𝜌21\rho^{2}\leq 1, we obtain the result.

For Corollary 3.3, we have γ​η=ℱρ​L​I​T𝛾𝜂ℱ𝜌𝐿𝐼𝑇\gamma\eta=\frac{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}}{\rho\sqrt{LIT}} according to the choice of γ𝛾\gamma and η𝜂\eta. Because ℱρ​L​I​T≤1L​I​Pℱ𝜌𝐿𝐼𝑇1𝐿𝐼𝑃\frac{\sqrt{\mathcal{F}}}{\rho\sqrt{LIT}}\leq\frac{1}{LIP}, we have γ​η≤1L​I​P𝛾𝜂1𝐿𝐼𝑃\gamma\eta\leq\frac{1}{LIP} and the conditions of Theorem 3.1 hold. The result is obtained by plugging the values of γ𝛾\gamma and η𝜂\eta into the result in Theorem 3.1, and noting that ρ2≤1superscript𝜌21\rho^{2}\leq 1 in the last term. ∎

Appendix D Additional Details and Results of Experiments

D.1 Additional Details of the Setup

Code. Please visit https://shiqiang.wang/code/fl-arbitrary-participation

Datasets. The FashionMNIST dataset333https://github.com/zalandoresearch/fashion-mnist has MIT license and a citation requirement [34]. The CIFAR-10 dataset444https://www.cs.toronto.edu/~kriz/cifar.html only has a citation requirement [19]. We have cited both papers in our main paper. Our experiments used the original split of training and test data in each dataset, where the training data is further split into workers in a non-IID manner according to the labels of data samples with a similarity of 5%percent55\%, as described in the main paper.

Motivation of the Setup. The non-IID splitting of data to clients and the periodic connectivity are motivated by application scenarios of FL. An example of a real-world scenario is where different geographically-dispersed user groups can participate in training at different times of the day, e.g., when their phones are charging during the night. Another example is where multiple organizations have their local servers (also known as edge servers), which can participate in training only when their servers are idle, such as during the night when there are few user requests, and these servers are located in different geographical regions. Our notion of “client” is a general term that can stand for the phone or the local server in these specific scenarios.

Availability of Clients. In the case of periodically available clients, as described in the main paper, subsets of clients with different majority class labels take turns to become available. For example, only those clients with the first two majority classes of data are available in the first 100100100 rounds; then, in the next 100100100 rounds, only those clients with the next two majority classes of data are available, and so on. The majority class of each client is determined by the non-IID data partitioning. There are 101010 classes in total, so a full cycle of participation of all clients is 500500500 rounds. To avoid inherent synchronicity across different simulation instances, we apply a random offset in the participation cycle at the beginning of the FL process. With this random offset, the number of rounds where the first subset of clients participate can be decreased to less than 100100100. For example, the first subset of clients may participate for 373737 rounds (an arbitrary number that is less than or equal to 100100100), the second subset of clients then participates for the next 100100100 rounds, and so on. This random offset varies across different simulation instances. It represents the practical scenario where the FL process can start at any time in the day. In each round, S=10𝑆10S=10 clients are selected to participate, according to a random permutation among the currently available clients. The selection of a small number of clients among the available clients can be due to resource efficiency considerations, for instance.

In addition to periodic availability, we also consider a setting where all the N=250𝑁250N=250 clients are always available, and a subset of S=10𝑆10S=10 clients are selected to participate in each round. Here, we consider two participation patterns. For independent participation, the subset of clients are selected randomly according to a uniform distribution, independently across rounds. For regularized participation, the clients are first randomly permuted and then S𝑆S clients are selected sequentially from the permuted sequence of clients, so that all the N𝑁N clients participate in FL once in every NS𝑁𝑆\frac{N}{S} rounds.

Hyperparameter Choices. The initial local learning rates of γ=0.1𝛾0.1\gamma=0.1 and γ=0.05𝛾0.05\gamma=0.05 for FashionMNIST and CIFAR-10, respectively, were obtained from a learning rate search where the model was trained using γ∈{0.5,0.1,0.05,0.01,0.005,0.001,0.0005,0.0001}𝛾0.50.10.050.010.0050.0010.00050.0001\gamma\in\{0.5,0.1,0.05,0.01,0.005,0.001,0.0005,0.0001\} while fixing η=1𝜂1\eta=1. We considered the case of always available clients for this learning rate search. We chose the learning rate that gave the smallest training loss after 2,00020002,000 rounds of training for FashionMNIST and 4,00040004,000 rounds of training for CIFAR-10, where we observed that the best learning rate is the same for both independent and regularized participation with each dataset. The reason of considering always available clients for tuning the initial learning rates is because this is the ideal case which allows the model to make big steps in training, so it is reasonable to use these learning rates as starting points even in the case of periodic availability. The number of rounds that use the initial learning rate in the case of periodic availability was determined so that the model’s performance no longer improves substantially afterwards, if keeping the same initial learning rate.

The subsequent learning rates for the methods shown in Figure 1, with periodically available clients, are found from a search on a grid that is {1,0.1,0.01,0.001,0.0001}10.10.010.0010.0001\{1,0.1,0.01,0.001,0.0001\} times the initial learning rate, as described in the main paper. The optimal learning rates found from this search are shown in Table D.1.

We fix the number of local updates to I=5𝐼5I=5 and use a minibatch size of 161616 for local SGD at each participating client. These parameters were not tuned specifically, since the relative difference between different methods will likely follow the same trend for different I𝐼I and minibatch sizes. Because I𝐼I is a controllable parameter in our experiments, we consider a minor extension (compared to our discussion in Section 5) in the “wait-*” methods in our experiments, where each client performs I𝐼I local iterations (instead of one iteration in the discussion in Section 5) before starting to wait. The intuition remains the same as what has been discussed in Section 5. The reason for this extension is because the “wait-*” methods defined in this way is equivalent to the case where all the clients are available but the total number of rounds is reduced by P𝑃P, so it has an easily interpretable meaning in practice. In addition, changing I𝐼I can change the performance of all methods (including Algorithm 1, both with and without amplification, and the “wait-*” methods), while their relative difference can remain similar. We do not study the effect of I𝐼I and minibatch size in details in this work.

Model Architecture. The CNN architectures used in our experiments are shown in Table D.2, where we use Kaiming initialization [15] for all the ReLU layers. All convolutional and dense layers, except for the last layer, use ReLU activation.

Collecting Results. The plots in Figures 1–2 and all the figures showing additional results in the next section were obtained from simulations with 101010 different random seeds for FashionMNIST and 555 different random seeds for CIFAR-10. For the best viewing experience, we further applied moving average over a window length of 3%percent33\% of the data points (on the x𝑥x-axis) in the loss and accuracy results. In all the figures, the solid lines and the shaded areas show the average and standard deviation values, respectively, over the moving average window and all simulation runs for each configuration.

Computational Resources. The workload of experiments was split between a desktop machine with RTX 3070 GPU and an internal GPU cluster. On RTX 3070, the FashionMNIST experiment with 300,000300000300,000 training rounds takes about a day to complete for a single simulation instance; the CIFAR-10 experiment with 600,000600000600,000 training rounds takes about three days to complete for a single simulation instance. The RTX 3070 has memory that can support simulation with 555 different random seeds (i.e., 555 different instances) at the same time. On the internal GPU cluster, the running times are slightly shorter since it has better-performing GPUs. We also note that the “wait-*” methods run faster than Algorithm 1 in simulation because a lot of rounds are skipped, but this does not mean that they can train models faster in practice, because we consider the number of training rounds as an indication of physical time elapse. For example, in the case of periodic availability, each subset of clients is available for 100100100 rounds in a cycle. This means that 100100100 rounds of training can take place during the physical time duration that these clients are available. Algorithm 1 chooses to actually train models during this time. The “wait-*” methods choose not to train in some of the rounds, but they still need to wait until the time has passed and the next subset of clients becomes available, where the time here is measured by the number of training rounds that includes those rounds that may be skipped by the “wait-*” methods.

D.2 Additional Results

In the following, we present some additional results obtained from experiments.

D.2.1 Always Available Clients

We first consider the case of always available clients, where a subset of S=10𝑆10S=10 clients are selected in an independent or regularized manner, as discussed in Section D.1. We compare the results of independent and regularized participation in Figure D.1. The observation is that both methods give similar performance, with regularized participation having a marginal performance improvement. As our theory predicts (see Table 1), both independent and regularized participation can guarantee convergence, where regularized participation gives a slightly better convergence rate.

D.2.2 Periodically Available Clients

Different Learning Rates and Amplification Factors. Next, we consider periodically available clients as in the main paper. We study the performance of Algorithm 1 with different learning rate and amplification factor configurations. The results are shown in Figures D.2 and D.3.

Figure D.2 shows the results with different combinations of the local learning rate γ𝛾\gamma and amplification factor η𝜂\eta. We note that η=1𝜂1\eta=1 corresponds to the case without amplification and η=10𝜂10\eta=10 corresponds to the case with amplification (and with an amplification factor of 101010). We can observe that when γ𝛾\gamma is large, the training is generally unstable with high fluctuation, high loss, and low accuracy. Reducing γ𝛾\gamma improves the performance. According to our theory, P=500𝑃500P=500 gives a small δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) with this experimental setup, because the cycle of all clients being available once is 500500500 rounds. On the other hand, a small δ~2​(P)superscript~𝛿2𝑃\tilde{\delta}^{2}(P) can be achieved with a much smaller P𝑃P in the case of always available clients (in Section D.2.1). When P𝑃P gets large, our theory suggests that the learning rate γ𝛾\gamma should become small in order to guarantee convergence. This explains why non-convergence is observed in Figure D.2 for large γ𝛾\gamma, while convergence is observed for small γ𝛾\gamma. For the smallest γ𝛾\gamma in each case, i.e., γ=10−5𝛾superscript105\gamma=10^{-5} for FashionMNIST and γ=5×10−6𝛾5superscript106\gamma=5\times 10^{-6} for CIFAR-10, we can see that amplification with η=10𝜂10\eta=10 further improves the performance over no amplification (η=1𝜂1\eta=1).

In Figure D.3, we further investigate the impact of different amplification factors η𝜂\eta, while fixing γ=10−5𝛾superscript105\gamma=10^{-5} for FashionMNIST and γ=5×10−6𝛾5superscript106\gamma=5\times 10^{-6} for CIFAR-10 as in the case of η=10𝜂10\eta=10 in Figure D.2. We observe that the cases with η=5𝜂5\eta=5, η=10𝜂10\eta=10, and η=15𝜂15\eta=15 have similar performance, especially when getting closer to convergence. The performance gets worse when η𝜂\eta is too small (e.g., η=2𝜂2\eta=2), because the advantage of amplification is not fully attained in this case. When η𝜂\eta is too large (e.g., η=20𝜂20\eta=20), we observe higher fluctuation in the loss and accuracy values, which also leads to lower performance. For both datasets and their corresponding models considered in our experiments, we observe that the cases of η=5𝜂5\eta=5, η=10𝜂10\eta=10, and η=15𝜂15\eta=15 all give reasonably good performance. This suggests that a coarse choice of η𝜂\eta based on experience can be sufficient in practice, without the need of fine-grained tuning.
